newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia govt outlays A$520 mln in R&D funds.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia govt outlays A$520 mln in R&D funds.

text.p: Australian Industry Minister John Moore said on Thursday the government would provide A$520 million in funding over the next four years to help companies with their research and development (R&D) expenditure.

The funding was budgeted for in the government's August 30 budget with A$40 million of the total to be available in the 1996/97 fiscal year regardless of whether parliament approves an offsetting cut in a R&D tax break.
"It overcomes the flaws in the previous system of syndications, in which the focus was more on financial outcomes rather than R&D outcomes," Moore told reporters.

However, he said the remaining A$480 million was conditional on the successful passage of the government's R&D tax break legislation through the non-government dominated upper house, the Senate. Companies can currently deduct 150 percent of R&D spending from their taxable income, but the government wants to cut this to 125 percent.
The Labor opposition is opposed to the change, while the Australian Democrats have said they are open to negotiations.
The government needs two non-government votes to pass any legislation in the Senate.
"I think that the outcome in the Senate is by no means set in cement," Moore said.
"We're having discussions with various parties and may find different voting patterns on different subjects."
Moore said the government currently spent about A$3.5 billion a year on R&D.
